title: Scene 4: Discharge or Detention
text:
It’s been four days.

You’ve been silent, compliant, maybe even chemically obedient. You haven’t seen a mirror. You haven’t heard your own voice. But something inside you still whispers: you exist.

Today they tell you there’s a 'meeting.' No one asks if you feel better. No one tells you who signed your hold.

You're seated across from a clipboard. A nurse you've never seen takes notes while pretending not to.

You’re told your behavior has 'improved.' You’re told there’s a possibility you’ll be released today. You’re told this is your 'last chance' to cooperate.

But you know better now. You’ve seen the cracks. You know this system wasn’t built to discharge people like you. It was built to forget them.

choices.text: Nod and say thank you. Pretend it was all just a misunderstanding.
choices.result: You’re discharged. No meds. No follow-up. You’re given a trash bag of your belongings and a list of local shelters.

choices.text: Ask who filed the hold, who reviewed it, who signed the extension.
choices.result: You’re told to calm down. The nurse flags you for 'increased agitation.' The review is 'paused.'

choices.text: Stay silent. There’s nothing left to say.
choices.result: They take your silence as compliance. You’re quietly placed under extended observation, indefinitely.
